movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

It is both plodding and a work of cinematic genius.
A savage, sicko, slasher flick.
Unfortunately, Andy Fickman's fussy family saga fails the funny test, despite a few random highlights.

After Earth might have worked as an episode in the Star Trek series, circa 1966-69. As a big Hollywood sci-fi adventure for the summer of 2013, it just seems uninspired, tired and sometimes ridiculous.
The language of currency on screen is English. The tone is von Trier. The focus is fuzzy.
Interstellar is the most ambitious, intelligent and daring space epic since Stanley Kubrick's masterpiece, 2001: A Space Odyssey.

Mockingjay - Part 1 is as dingy and dark as Blade Runner, but just as fascinating. No more party dresses catching fire. No more fantasy games. In their place is a war tableau that seems realistic, even if this is a futuristic fantasy film.
As politically savvy as it is raucous and funny, Barbershop: The Next Cut is a stylish cut above its predecessors.
Criminal is a screwed-up mess as a story and as an action movie with a so-called moral lesson in it. In fact, the more I think about it, the less I like it.
The relentless action flick Hardcore Henry is totally nuts and a lot of fun for freaks.
Half of Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is brilliant. Unfortunately, the other half of Zack Snyder's epic-length superhero movie is so bloated that it blunts the effect of the good stuff.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Never subtle, always strident and absolutely necessary.
The result is a slam-dunk candidate for best animated feature in next year's Oscars. But the pleasure now comes in appreciating the sumptuous artistry.
An incoherent and idiotic mess.
Turning the usual boy-meets-girl conventions topsy-turvy -- and letting women decide whether it is better to be with, or move on from the men in their lives -- is refreshing and interesting.

Stacked with an all-star cast led by George Clooney, Josh Brolin and Scarlett Johansson, and packed with 1950s details about how the Hollywood studio system operated in all its self-indulgent glory in that era, Hail, Caesar! is a sly satire.
This American movie is wretchedly written and badly directed and edited.
There is so much to like and admire and study closely, including DiCaprio's mature, committed, ruthless and yet empathetic performance.
The Hateful Eight is a crackling yarn with a deep well of meaning and socio-political commentary.
Walt Disney Studios' splendid new version of The Jungle Book is utterly charming, absolutely gorgeous and perhaps too terrifying for the youngest and most impressionable children.
David O. Russell brings his Joy to the world with a wonky sense of humour and the genius of young actress Jennifer Lawrence.
We get to spend a lot of fun and/or dramatic time with Ford's Solo, while Ridley's Rey and Boyega's Finn give us a pair of dynamic new heroes to follow in future Star Wars Episodes.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is mounted as a handsome period piece in period style, except for the modern special effects to make the close-ups of the whale look real. But it is also a bridge to modern thinking and a desperately thrilling adventure story.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Creed is not just a knockout boxing movie, it coaxes Rocky Balboa off the mat and revives an iconic American hero.
The Good Dinosaur is a good movie for young audiences -- and for parents who want to share a prehistoric moral fable with their children.
The Hunger Games, which kicked off in a blaze of guts 'n' glory in 2012, ends now with a sad whimper, along with a lot of big bangs signifying nothing.
The new movie is profane, insane, politically incorrect, religiously irreverent and ridiculously funny.
Some of the members of the Cooper clan are interesting enough, and the movie's tearjerking heart is in the right place, but Love the Coopers is a horrible mess.
An adrenaline rush of action, insight, drama, pathos, brutality, humility, humanity and even the occasional whisper of mischievous comedy.
[Bullock] has the knack of playing someone who is seriously flawed, yet still appealing for her smarts, her broken heart and her sharp wit.
It is not even bad enough to be good camp comedy.
Remember is not a true story, yet could felt real if the plot had been as convincing as Plummer's performance.

Steve Jobs the man was complicated - and often infuriating to family, friends and colleagues at Apple Inc., the computer company he co-founded. Steve Jobs the film is also complicated -- and consistently thrilling.
You feel that there is a good and maybe even a meaningful comedy here. But it never gets its act together.
The Huntsman: Winter's War is as beautiful as its macho lead actor Chris Hemsworth is handsome. The movie is also as vacuous, silly and boring as Hemsworth is awkward and awful in the title role.
The stupid plot, dismal dialogue, moral turpitude and dispiriting torpor of this movie makes watching it utterly pointless.
If you do not count Guardians of the Galaxy -- because it remains an eccentric outlier -- Civil War now easily ranks as the best movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Live by Night is a solid, interesting but sprawling and often overwrought gangster picture.

Silence requires a leap of faith in its own right. The film is both repetitive and thrilling; it is boring and exhilarating; it will test your patience and expand your mind. Silence is loud, in an astonishingly quiet way.

Serious or not, many films are merely entertainments and are easily forgotten, even if they succeed. But a serious film such as Fences is a privilege to see, not just as a dramatic entertainment but because it reverberates long after it ends.
Assassin's Creed slays me: I have rarely had so much fun watching something so stupid.
Rogue One: A Star Wars Story does exactly what it is supposed to do by incrementally expanding the Star Wars universe that we already know.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Unless you are an utterly immovable cynic, the Australian melodrama Lion will coax out tears of sadness and of pure joy.
A bitter disappointment.
Paying respect and homage to the Polynesian culture and its ancient mythology, the Walt Disney animation Moana is as culturally rich as it is entertaining.

The Edge of Seventeen is charming, thoughtful, a little crazy, often funny and sometimes touching in a very real way. It makes you feel that the high school movie genre still has merit, even in Hollywood hands.
While it falters and even bogs down at moments in the storytelling, Beasts is a dazzling spectacle overall and more often spellbinding than not.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ouija: Origin of Evil is sadly derivative, totally stupid, routinely cheeseball and ultimately disappointing.

I would strongly suggest that only those people who are already on-board with Hart's profane, raucous, scatological and often rude family humour go to see this film. If you feel neutral or negative already,

The only reason to endure this dismal story is to watch Blunt strut her stuff.
Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is worth a visit. Just don't stay too long. It could be dangerous for your health.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While the drama here is straight forward and conventional, Stone turns a brilliant trick by visually showing how computer spying is conducted. We do not have to understand how it works to appreciate what it does -- because Stone skillfully shows us.
It may not be a classic, but it is enormously crowd-pleasing for the story and its reminder that ordinary people can do extraordinary things in a crisis.

Free State of Jones is a great opportunity lost.
I like Central Intelligence, even when it is being stupid.
Finding Dory is delightful throughout, dazzling during its many highlight scenes and just a tad disorienting on rare occasions.
Me Before You will jerks some tears, maybe even from cynics.
Alice, of Alice in Wonderland fame, is dead to me now. Alice Through the Looking Glass has killed her off as a viable character for a movie.

It creates great on-screen chemistry between Gosling and Crowe - as brute adversaries who partner up as private eyes to solve a criminal conspiracy. And it blows your mind with its sense of absurdity - even while making the crime caper count.

Piece by piece, Singer fits this ninth film in the franchise (which includes Deadpool) into the X-Men universe like a master puzzle maker. He does it so well, at least in terms of storytelling, that the X-Men franchise still has a vigorous future.
The film could be better -- and it should be better, considering the depth of the talent involved.
This Goosebumps ride may be bumpy, but it works and it is worthwhile.
What seemed fresh and silly and naive and hilarious in 1994 - like the cascading joke sequence about the most annoying sound in the world - now seems contrived and repetitive and sometimes repulsive.

Sometimes murky and yet often magical.

Fifty Shades of Grey only has one shade: tedious self-pity. The other 49 shades promised in the title are missing from the movie version of the infamous novel.
The dialogue in Seventh Son is dismal. The plotting is awkward. Nothing much works as storytelling. But even those problems are overshadowed by the accents -- the source of much of the hilarity.
It instantly rates as one of the most dismal animations ever released under the Disney umbrella.
Michael Mann's Blackhat is supposed to be a hack attack thriller. Instead, it is a bloody bore.
Utterly beguiling and totally eccentric, Paddington is the first theatrical movie to tell the story of the beloved bear from darkest Peru.

movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The premise is pretty much the same: Mess with Neeson's loved ones and you will die.

With Ebert's blessing and encouragement, Life Itself is a warts-and-all look at how the son of an Illinois electrician and housewife became a prolific writer who spent 46 years as the film critic at the Chicago Sun Times.
Wes Anderson's latest opus, The Grand Budapest Hotel, is bloody bonkers and simply splendid.
A word about the film's epic length. Boyhood is 166 minutes long. Yet it is so affecting, so much a thing of wonder, that it could run forever and I would still keep watching.

A fun romp with nothing much to remember.
The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies is a thrilling and a fitting end to an extraordinary fantasy adventure.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There is nothing unique about the film itself - except for the mesmerizing performance by Benedict Cumberbatch in the lead role.
Too episodic, too halting, too disjointed to be credited as an accomplished comedy.
Some may find it sour and even repulsive, with its pathological anarchy of flavours. Some will find it delicious, in a deliriously exotic manner. Count me in the second camp.

Because I found the original movie so engaging, I enjoyed finding out what has happened, and what is to come, in the lives of these characters.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unfinished Business has a big heart, a tiny brain and a lot of bad attitude. That turns it into a murky mess as a movie.

A near-perfect balance of humour, pathos, adventure and poignant emotion. That makes it great entertainment for children and adults. The film is sophisticated, intelligent and heartfelt -- plus a ton of fun, too.

While the doc takes a conventional and even pedestrian approach -- with multiple talking-head interviews and some re-enactments with actors -- there is also plenty of spectacular archival footage showing jumps dating back to the 1960s.

San Andreas does exactly what it set out to do: Satisfy the thrill-seekers with a popcorn movie. If you want something more serious about earthquakes, you have to watch the nightly news.

No one can quibble with the efforts of the actors. Marvel cast well, and continues to expand their parts or add fascinating new players.

Gorgeous, elegant and wondrous, the new live-action Cinderella is a jewel in Disney's treasure trove.

Heart-wrenching but ultimately inspirational.
The acting is universally abysmal, although so are all the lines of dialogue. So I can't entirely blame the cast members.

An exquisite drama brimming with life and laughter and great tenderness and wrenching tragedy.

[Wenders and Shepard] ramble the stark countryside, two filmmakers in search of meaning. Interesting, beautiful to watch, but pointless.

Comes with the shapely narrative of such animated classics as Bambi and The Lion King, and yet the penguins are all quite real.

movie_review_blurb: A corrosive confection of style and bile, its gleaming, butter cream-frosted contours not really concealing the crumbs who have curdled British society with their drugs.

I think I liked Aniston's old friends better.

movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: The most audacious pop-cultural amalgam since Star Wars.
In terms of story and characters, this film pirouettes into the orchestra pit.
Though its tale of gold is not untarnished, The Road to El Dorado hits the buddy-movie mark.
Spending 95 minutes with the slight antics of Pikachu, Ash and the gang may seem like an eternity.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The wow-factor action is irresistible, and Lloyd is no less appealing than '60s Disney star Kevin Corcoran.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever you do, don't close your mind to such an inventive concoction. One last time, despite all your better instincts, go ahead -- open that theater door.
Another SNL misfire.
Among today's rude, crude and gleefully non-PC comedies, Scary Movie can be so funny it's scary.
Action flicks should be fun, and this one is a bloody bore.
As in The Haunting, they eventually surrender characters and story to computer-generated spectacle, squandering any creepy immediacy and trampling the human element.
The real fun of Scream 2, like Scream, isn't seeing people slaughtered. It's the smart-mouth dialogue and in-joke ironies.
As good as [Close] is, she's simply Cruella revisited.
Stretched far too thin for its meager plot, broad characters and lame running jokes.
The key to appreciating The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas is low expectations.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining lark that's often spry and even radiant, with an end-credit wrap-up that's a hoot.
This film stands out -- not as an original (its focus on fierce competition is nothing new), but as a well-executed story with likable characters and fresh flourishes.
You're bound to scream -- perhaps real loud -- but it may be out of impatient dismay as much as Pavlovian reaction.
A lovably amusing foray into vapid plotting, bad dubbing and men in rubber suits trashing miniature sets.
In a summer driven by wow factors, Titan A.E. has a galaxy's worth.
Its sentiment is rote, its truths are culled from a trip down the aisles of a greeting-card shop.
A highly entertaining romantic comedy that is so sweet, funny and charming.
The Watcher is a numbingly familiar exercise in fear, disgorging regular doses of grisly violence buoyed by precious little plot and pitifully thin character development.
Aardman delivers the most consistently entertaining animated film in years.
A rare teen film that spends less time pandering to wish-fulfilling fantasies than baring honest interpersonal realities.
As it is, it's one of Burton's lesser works -- above the goofy Mars Attacks!, but below Sleepy Hollow and his Batman films when it comes to earnest adventure.
Unlike most such sex comedies, it's not mean-spirited. Instead, like the original, it's an odd mix of ribaldry and innocence, titillation and tenderness, lasciviousness and love.
If anything, it's the filmmakers who seem insulated, working cluelessly within the plastic bubble of Hollywood.
A fresh hybrid of zombie horror, high-tech sci-fi and butt-kicking thrill ride.
When it's not glorifying baseball and Texas myths, The Rookie zips like a good fastball.
Frailty isn't as gory or explicit. But in its child-centered, claustrophobic context, it can be just as frightening and disturbing -- even punishing.
In its ragged, cheap and unassuming way, the movie works.
If you're a fan of the Friday the 13th series, its 10th and latest entry, Jason X, should not disappoint.
With Hollywood Ending, he's made three solid comedies in a row, each a light lark with no hint of morose self-reflection.
In the end there is one word that best describes this film: honest.
For a film about action, Ultimate X is the gabbiest giant-screen movie ever, bogging down in a barrage of hype.
In short, a film dependent on deception relies on the Clark Kent school of disguise, and it doesn't work.
For decades we've marveled at Disney's rendering of water, snow, flames and shadows in a hand-drawn animated world. Prepare to marvel again.
Parker keeps things light and lively, and the cast never trips over Wilde's eloquence.
Toward the end Sum of All Fears morphs into a mundane '70s disaster flick.
while [Roman Coppola] scores points for style, he staggers in terms of story.
While dutifully pulling on heartstrings, directors Dean Deblois and Chris Sanders valiantly keep punching up the mix.
Mr. Deeds isn't bad for an Adam Sandler film, which is as backhanded as a compliment can get.
An artful yet depressing film that makes a melodramatic mountain out of the molehill of a missing bike.
MIB II is faithful to its source film, which in turn sprang from a comic book. But this feels more like submission to formula than devotion to inspiration.
A more enjoyable neo-dragon flick than 1981's Dragonslayer, with its lesser effects, or 1996's Dragonheart, with its soft heart for the monsters.
This new spin on the old switcheroo plot is intriguing, warmly human and gently funny.
Freaks is yet another case of plot and characters playing second fiddles to an orchestra of visuals.
It reminds us that Nathan Lane is the best show stealer in show business.
If you enjoy the tense claustrophobia of submarine thrillers, K-19 fills the bill.
Performances are potent, and the women's stories are ably intercut and involving.
[T]hose same extremes prevent us from taking its message seriously, and the Stepford Wives mentality doesn't work in a modern context.
An honest, sensitive story from a Vietnamese point of view.
Tadpole is emblematic of the witless ageism afflicting films: Young is cool, and too young is too cool.
Spy Kids 2 is loose and lively and appeals to the kid in all of us.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: For all its alleged youthful fire, XXX is no less subservient to Bond's tired formula of guns, girls and gadgets while brandishing a new action hero.
It's Hollywood navel-gazing at its best.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: For a film by a photographer, it's awfully unfocused.
Gedeck is mostly marvelous.
The far future may be awesome to consider, but from period detail to matters of the heart, this film is most transporting when it stays put in the past.

As the story of heroic response to tragic illness, Iris is the kind of film often cynically pegged a 'disease of the week' movie. But unlike such formulaic TV productions, Iris' heroine is denied the capacity to be inspiring.
Summer Catch is supposed to be end-of -summer fun, but it's about as fun as learning to eat your spinach.
Jeepers Creepers gets down and dirty, respecting its genre enough to make it seem vibrant, fresh and, in a warped way, real.
This may be a slow film, but there are worse settings for aimlessness.
It works well in narrative terms, thanks to strong characters and surprising respect for the music.
For an exploitation flick, Soul Survivors also is woefully slow.
Hardball is an unpleasant tale of questionable redemption for a guy who rightly says, 'I'm just a loser.'
have risen above screenwriter Kate Lanier's mundane show-biz saga.
Put simply, the movie drags.
Children may enjoy its food fights, barf gags, slimy gross-outs, kid-power fantasies and adults' comic discomfiture, but there's not much here for anyone over 12.
This isn't just bad. It's an abject failure whose lame nuttiness evokes bad dinner theater more than a major studio movie.
Too much of its reality involves joyless response to circumstantial failure, and instead of being ironic or bittersweet, it's mostly bitter.
An affectionate, familial documentary giving credit to an unsung music hero.
A moody, mysterious fright film with a painterly beauty.
More bark than creepy bite.
It's an 800-pound gorilla of a movie, and now PDI has the challenge of answering back.
A martial-arts flick that transcends its genre with surprisingly strong sci-fi concepts.
Shows not how far we've come since '76, but how low comic standards have sunk.
As a romantic comedy on your film menu, Sidewalks of New York holds the romance and serves comedy on the side.
If you can tolerate its predictability, you may fall for Iron Ladies' lighthearted spirit and affectionate humor.
A breath of fresh, frisky air, even if it does hinge on cliches.
The infectious high spirits amid its cartoonish chaos compensate for the film's bald deficiencies and gag-inducing gags.
[Anderson] makes us laugh, he makes us think, and he does it in a distinctive screwball style.
There's still room in this world for innocent love stories -- and tales as old as time.
The pace is so lethargic and the focus so diffuse that it's hard to get a fix on Charlotte beyond needless glamorization.
The movie's magic is that we feel more rewarded than manipulated.
Unlike Rushmore, Slackers sends subtlety and cleverness to the back of the class, while labored lunacy wears its dunce cap front row, center.
For all its failings, Wet Hot maintains energy and high spirits over most of its length. The trouble is, such energy and spirits are not infectious, and the movies it mocks were better.
Teetering toward preaching, the film says much about courage, honor, duty and sacrifice, traits common enough in many World War II stories.
Preceded by a 1957 Pluto short, Never Land is a warmly nostalgic throwback.
A base guy flick that's clueless about women, relationships and emotion, and even flirts with sacrilege.
Newcomer Land is a find, performing with guileless naturalism and resilient dignity.
Compelling but punishing -- an artful ordeal. The best way to process it may be as unintended camp, rolling your eyes in amazement at its litany of misery and heaps of histrionics.
Portentous and pretentious, Shell 2 crawls along like a machine on low batteries.
Too often it seems to be just another action fantasy that teaches pacifism while indulging in brutality.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As is typical of many weddings, the planning drags, and so does the movie.
Though lovely and scenic, it drones for thousands of miles.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Valor does emerge in The Guardian, but often is eclipsed by an effects-driven star vehicle.
The film's first half has zero to do with its title, and its second half digs up familiar turf.
Even fantasies need a nod or a wink to assure viewers, 'Yes, it's ludicrous -- but isn't it fun?'
Perhaps indoctrination is in the eye of the beholder. But one thing is certain: All Christians aren't the same. I'm one, and I found this film to be saddening, not heartening.
Despite the buzz about its hard-core hanky-panky, writer-director John Cameron Mitchell paints a bland, bleak portrait of navel-gazing New Yorkers driven by carnal pleasures -- or lack of them.
It's more confusing than absorbing.
It's one of the most clear-headed -- and twistedly entertaining -- views of drug dependency and insanity I've ever seen.
We see not only the inner corridors of power, but also sense the inner workings of the royal mind. Stephen Frears' deft direction also gives the film insight and even humor.
Instead of an insightful look at disaffected youths finding an outlet for angry energy in rock rages, American Hardcore is a slanted history lesson coming solely from its subjects.
A Good Year builds so much fairy-tale contrivance with such boisterous high spirits that it's exhausting to keep feeling good about feeling good.
Dahlia seethes with atmosphere, and Hollywood's underbelly is always worth an ogle.
It's an ugly, brutal picture, and it's not about 'times' but rather timeless macho posturing run amok.
Linklater and Schlosser have plenty to say. They just fail to say it cohesively.

With so much brandishing of name actors in small roles, Bobby feels like a '70s disaster flick, with the disaster in the final minutes. While waiting, viewers must content themselves with playing spot-the-star.
Consider it a modern spin on Deliverance, with no squealing like a pig -- just squeals of frightful excitement.
The film is brief, thin and anecdotal. Yet at its heart is a loving look at an artist at work, and that artist is Morgan Freeman.
It's a good gimmick, but still a gimmick, and we're left with more confusion than tension.
Charlotte's Web adapts a classic, which is not to say it is one.
This is no heart-tugging family drama; rather it's a contemplative, compassionate portrait of a hardy people. Offered as a borderline documentary, it proceeds in long, uncluttered takes.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Just as the French may overrate our cinema (Jerry Lewis, anyone?), we may overrate theirs. Take Le Petit Lieutenant -- please.
A dramatic crisis erupts in bloodbaths that are filled with flash but little meaning. As armies clash, the cast also yields to histronic extremes.
The film becomes a sermonette on tolerance. But with its one-sidedness, it fails to practice what it preaches.
This film fails to earn what Erin Gruwell earned in real life: credibility.

Known in the United States for her whimsical books, Potter was an ecological champion in the United Kingdom. The film touches on this, but mostly it's a tender tale about yearning hearts and courageous idealism.
Harris, who adapted the screenplay, and director Peter Webber are faithful to his book. Strong production values, a lush score and scenic locations work seal the deal.
Forget Scarface and Miami Vice. Cocaine Cowboys is the real deal -- a down-and-dirty look at the high living and illegal drugs that dominated south Florida in the 1980s.
When Sedgwick's whirl of liberation turns into addiction, clichÃ©s stall the plot.
Iraq for Sale isn't balanced or objective. It carries the torch for the families of civilians who died while driving unprotected trucks on unsafe routes.
movie_title: Iraq for Sale: The War Profiteers (2006)

movie_review_blurb: More a series of anecdotes than an insightful dramedy and relies too much on absurd coincidences and needless sitcom-style lying.
This listless biopic of the famed 1950s model is as timid and tame as her photos seem today.
As is evident by the film's strong start and faltering finale, the trouble with any promise is failing to keep it.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Below its surface, Water isn't about religion, politics or even India. It's about timeless and universal divides between people, when humanity is eclipsed by self-serving subjugation.

Instead of a laudable ecological crusade, the film feels more like a futile Captain Ahab obsession, with patrol leader Ri Tai (Duobujie) vainly chasing a poaching kingpin through the harsh, windy wilderness.

Through it all, Jentsch is a beacon of bravery and resolve in the darkness of a totalitarian machine. If any actor in an English-language film has given a better performance in the past year, I'd like to see it.
It's a predictable and preachy stab at a comedy with heart, and its subversive silliness is eclipsed by an overwrought humanity.
Its coming-of-age yarn goes nowhere beyond inevitably out of a closet.
Like too many films, Down in the Valley turns on its viewers.
You're not getting the whole picture in Ocean Oasis, just the critter-cute ones. But at least the film is well shot, showing striking vistas and images both above and beneath the waves.
District B-13 is bad sci-fi, but it succeeds as mindless action.
Nondevotees also should find a home in this agreeable, accessible Companion.
Assayas tells her tale sympathetically, but this sad saga lacks substance. He sells the wretch but not the redemption.
The bottom line is that none of this goes anywhere beyond a droning funeral procession.
The film's focus shouldn't be Dot (Camilla Belle), a deaf, mute and orphaned teen. It should be her new family of suburbanites sliding into hell.
The web gets more tangled until, midway through, the drama drops and the film becomes yet another bloody horror show.
It's handsome and heartfelt but mired in murky politics, plot inertia, musical montages and painfully pointed symbolism.
Squanders plot impetus, and even with constant crosscutting it's lethargically paced, slogging through soap-operatic back stories and maddening irrelevancies.
It's often unclear what's going on, beyond a zillion dollars of splashy effects washing over the screen.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Steeped in urban-youth woes but gets a bounce from Clark's sense of humor and hope.
We hardly get to know Cohen from the biographical shorthand melded to a worshipful tribute show in which the Canadian singer-songwriter never even appears.
Some things were meant to be seen in small doses or on small screens. For all its subversive perks and quirks, Strangers is one of them.
Director Ivan Reitman, who's been busting our guts since Ghost Busters, stirs a high-concept stew of Fatal Attraction meets The Incredibles.
Scoop, an amiable romp of lighthearted fun.
More intriguing than enthralling, more creepy than disturbing, The Night Listener runs a tidy 80 minutes yet still feels stretched.
The Descent seems less about female empowerment than female misery. One wonders if Marshall has issues. No males suffer here, just women who, even if they survive, won't ever be the same again.

For a film about magic, The Illusionist doesn't depend on tricks up its sleeve. It's more about artfulness, from handsome period details and Philip Glass' urgent score to an intriguing and vibrant plot.
Sometimes, keeping it real is all we ask, and this film gets the job done.
I felt some of its heroine's pain. She's spent her life waiting for an orgasm. I spent the movie waiting for a plot.
More disturbing than thrilling, Lemming, like Alice, overstays its welcome, but does get around to a finishing kick.
Their journey isn't over -- many in Africa still desperately need help -- but the hope and opportunities America offers are a grand place to start.
How do we loathe thee, The Number 23? Let us count the ways.
Milking sympathy for parentless children is no stretch in The Italian. More impressive is its affecting look at their reeling mother country.
On sci-fi's crowded table Boyle serves a fresh feast for our eyes, minds and hearts.
The film seduces. Beautifully produced, from production design and costumes to music and performances, it's also faithful to the genteel spirit and repressed passions for which she's known.
As an alleged witty comedy of humanistic charm, it sags in both, thanks to unfunny predicaments and a phony plot.
I'll just say that Buscemi, who also directed and co-wrote, knows a lot about making movies but little about journalism.
A punishing misfire.
This lurid lunacy from New Zealand is a horror-humor cross-breed of animal lore and giddy gore.
Perhaps the Bible needs an 11th Commandment: Thou Shalt Not Bore. That might stem misfires such as The Ten.
Resistance is futile -- unless your screenplay can offer pat, absurd plot turns.
Borrowing from too many movies to count, Rocket Science botches that brew in an unwieldy slew of adolescent-angst clichÃ©s.
It may be the most depressing action movie ever made. Its calamities are well staged, and its acting, beyond some histrionics, is fine. But you don't enjoy this film; you endure it.
If you want dangerous schemes to be light-hearted entertainment, you've got to make allowances. Besides, the payoffs are worth it - in any language.

The best Western since Unforgiven, 3:10 to Yuma is both cathartic and intelligent. While a wildly eventful action-adventure and outlaw shoot-'em-up, it's also a vibrant story of heroism, villainy and hard-earned redemption.
A drama that's so potent and persuasive yet also natural and intimate that it almost has the heft of a documentary.
Some offbeat humor shines through the clouds of this glum domestic drama, especially when fun friends shift the focus from Jean's grating histrionics. But it never lasts long.
What it's really about, more than sensitivity for displaced people or social analyses, is violence -- hideous, gruesome, over-the-top violence.
Nerds rule.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For this gripping and amazing documentary, such truth emerges not just from the facts, but also the poetry of men who redefine themselves in a risky race on small sailboats.
Sea of Dreams purports to be a film of 'magic realism,' but it's neither magical nor realistic.
[Haggis'] self-serious tone becomes wearisome, and he fails to explore how the military failed its men while clumsily laying a guilt trip at its feet.
Though Shadow could use a bit more confessionals and a bit less history, it still succeeds as a reminder of America's can-do spirit at its best.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A buoyant coming-of-age adventure welded to an amiable wealth fantasy.
Director Robert Benton and screenwriter Allison Burnett tell a sobering, adult-geared tale of love's highs, lows and maddening twists and turns.
It's simply product for a pre-conditioned marketplace, pushing familiar buttons without doing anything remotely creative.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Mike Cahill explores Charlie's foolishness with funny-sad fondness.
An eye-popping tribute to the European range that's heaved heavenward since bulging from the Earth eons ago during continental drift.
A quietly compelling drama of hidden desperation and fierce passions.
A love-tolerate valentine to the city, it feels more real than the gangster-gorged mean streets of Martin Scorsese's The Departed, and just as tortured as Clint Eastwood's Mystic River.
A fascinating documentary.
Although the period-piece film has all the trappings, from beautiful people to an obligatory sense of tragedy, it never follows through. In fact, its love story needs a shove -- it just lies there.
Cassavetes supplies no easy answers or easy laughs, forgoing romantic-comedy beats in respect for Nora's desperation. Call this confection a romantic-dramedy with humor on wry.
I've been among the unbelievers, but Hollywood Dreams turned me around -- to a point. Perhaps it's because the film is among Jaglom's best, love him or leave him.
A film whose deft blend of action thrills and gallows humor packs a jaunty kick and a firing-range boom.
Wild Hogs isn't wild so much as a mild evocation of better fish-out-of-water flicks.

The most perverse thing about Zodiac isn't that its Hollywood's umpteenth serial-killer flick, when such crimes are rare in reality. It's that Zodiac, though based on actual crimes, is one of the dullest of these films to date.
It's a steamy, searing saga of rigorous redemption confronting creepy Southern seediness. But it's not nearly the wake-up call it could have been.

Monster movies tend to be as misunderstood as their creatures, but dating back to 1931's Frankenstein, some haven't been about scaring us so much as enlightening us. The Host does this while disgorging a lizardlike carnivore.
Somber but soulful, Premonition has a strong dramatic performance by Sandra Bullock and a gimmicky plot that doesn't grate until the end.
My Brother is a brave little film, with the emphasis on little. Shot on a shoestring, it lacks the polish of many indie efforts but compensates with bold casting and a big heart.

One problem is that Malkovich gets free rein to be Malkovich, the often showy actor, rather than Conway, a humble London travel agent. It's a grandstanding performance that's more about hamminess than substance.
For such a gritty indie film, it's galling that [Arquette] and his family are so handsomely photogenic in a generic Hollywood way. Where's the rebellious truth in that?
There's more love and heart in The Namesake than in many Hollywood dramas. I just wish the filmmakers had spread it around. Cross-cultural understanding should be a two-way street.
Flannel Pajamas is so gorged with gab it feels like a filibuster.
Its sad story is ultimately humane and compelling, thanks to some special faces placed in the saga.
Firehouse Dog is a wholesome throwback to a time before computer animators made animals talk and penguins hogged the glory.
A mixed-bag of a popcorn flick where more proves to be less.
Dialogue is a low priority in this film, which has less plot than most video games.
In my book it's high camp -- a thrill ride for emotion junkies.
It'll do nicely, thanks not only to sophisticated amusement but also to a gentlemanly hero who earns a place in our hearts.
Like a perm that won't grow away, it's stuck in the race-comedy mold of Barbershop, Barbershop 2 and Beauty Shop. Been there, done that hair.
It's not preachy or weepy. Instead, it's a lively yet meaningful romantic comedy that doesn't lose sight of its central mission: to entertain.
Offside is a slow slog through bloated scenes with little happening. Framed and shot like a crude documentary, it proceeds in long, clunky takes, as if an editor couldn't be bothered.
Gracie, a tale about a teen girl blazing trails in soccer, is worthy, but it's also formulaic to a fault.
For a voyeuristic medium, this tale of a voyeur does a poor job of prying into its own protagonist's life.
Given Luke Wilson's affability, it's also irresistibly charming. You may not buy the film's plot, but you'll invest in him as a man whose heart is always in the right place.
The cast shows spark and gusto, especially Laura Harris as a vulnerable yet intrepid survivor type and Danny Dyer as a bent druggie who straightens out long enough to fight back.
Even the least tales here flit by quickly enough to leave little bad aftertaste, and the best are savored like the last small bites of exquisite soufflÃ©s.
A noisy, incoherent, droning spectacle.
[The] plot is warmed-over Capra, and it's no wonderful-life yarn.
... though Crazy Love remains a far cry from heartening, it is more amusing than disturbing, especially given the cranky yet symbiotic couple of today.
Is it sci-fi? Fantasy? Idiocy? Mostly it's a droning mess -- pretty to look at but confounding to the point where you just don't care any more.
Its minutiae don't bring a lump in the throat -- just a drumming of the fingers.
... a documentary whose superficial image belies its profound impact.
Its strong cast is loud and lively, and the bickering banter has snap and drive.
Director Michael Apted tells the story with dry devotion to parliamentary procedurals and a worshipful approach to Wilberforce. But [actor] Gruffudd lacks the intensity and charisma to pull it off.
The Sentinel's brains may be mush, but its brawn is powered by superb stunts, high-tech gizmos and a potent sense of peril.
An overrated mound of misery.
Yet for a so-called exploitation film, Wax is slow to exploit. Its leisurely setup is a fright-challenged snooze, and at nearly two hours it's bloated for a slasher flick.
Less a faux documentary than a perversely amusing stab at the music world's harsh realities.
Revenge of the Sith is more of the same: wildly flamboyant effects serving weak characters, bad acting and obtuse plotting.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Exorcism aside, Dominion is well-acted, handsomely photographed and hauntingly scored.
Take a long, hard look at Parkhill's film, and you'll find too many i's undotted.
Brilliantly written, animated and performed, it not only bridges the child-adult divide, but also makes its kid-friendly humor smart in its own way.
The titular operation often yanks the film from big-screen sensation to a pedantic look at military procedures best suited to a TV documentary.
It's unfair to pigeonhole this meaningful human story in that genre, especially since it feels more real than some adult chick flicks. Besides, a good story is a good story.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Squinting through cardboard glasses you get at the door, you see washed-out colors, blurred images and not enough pop-out to merit the trade-off.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Green's heart, if not his head, seems in the right place. He's carrying the torch and holding it high, and his students seem to dig it.
So richly detailed and colorful that one almost aches from the beauty.
Herbie is a G -- for good, if not grand.
Win or lose, in an era of sports idols as rock stars, Yao is a breath of fresh air.
Land's gruesomely creative zombie atrocities stretch an R rating's limits like a bloody tendon about to snap.
[The writers are] so busy setting up the premise that they barely get around to exploiting it.
A rousing affirmation of nature's brilliance in the face of environmental challenge.
If you can handle its unconventional approach, you won't feel as if you're seeing a film so much as witnessing a living nightmare.
Screenwriter Gina Wendkos, working from Meg Cabot's novel, resorts to monotonous movie clichÃ©s: almost uniformly cruel classmates and a callous, cacophonous mob of media jackals.
The action is handled fairly well, but it's routine, and there's no satisfaction in seeing Todd waste men who are no more bloodthirsty than he is.
Some may find such wrenching realities shocking, if not reprehensible. Others may glean meaning in their starkness -- a meaning that transcends the film's despair with the power of its truth.
This film is so not-from-the-cookie-cutter, so unaccommodating of our expectations, that we can't anticipate where Anderson's going to take us. Every scene is a discovery or sly diversion.
A genuine fright classic.
What ensues is painfully horrific and reprehensible as entertainment.

You can embrace this movie's message, which has less to do with political agendas than basic human decency and the enduring power of love. And if that's not enough to make a film worthwhile, we don't know what is.
It's no knockout, but it's fun and gets the job done in a nonmalicious way, which more of today's punishing filmmakers should emulate.
A lame duck of a movie.

Its tale was more tame and thoughtful when Steven Spielberg, having done the related Artificial Intelligence, pitched it to Bay. But Bay, being Bay, punched it up, hiring script doctors to mainline some action.
We knew Spielberg had action chops, but didn't know he had this in him. This anti-E.T. is so rigorously realized it makes Independence Day look like Finding Neverland.
Like good drive-in fare from the '70s, this is all about sensation.
As dull as dust for much of its look at the Baja 1000.
A charming cash cow with cute twists to its tale.
Beyond Wahlberg's deft moves, School's dancing is leaden, not charming, and the only challenge is enduring the film's lumbering progress until it finally clicks at the end.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Brutal yet meaningful, agonizing yet touching, The Brotherhood of War is a harrowing but rewarding experience.
movie_title: Tae Guk Gi: The Brotherhood of War (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An ambitious, if uneven, tale of passionate lovers from 1933 to 1945.

Shrilly pandering to edgy, jive-talking, hip-hopping bents of the moment, [Shark Tale] churns up a sea of offensive ethnic stereotypes, unfunny situations, unsympathetic characters and lousy plotting.
Best savored as a beautifully photographed and scored road trip and as a character study of disparate men who somehow fit together as friends.
Its preachy side can be offputting. Messages of forgiveness and spiritual awakening are slammed home like force-feeding for the soul.
A weird road-trip spin on Sam Peckinpah's Straw Dogs.
Though Team America has knee-slapping moments, too much mirth has too little on its mind.

movie_review_blurb: Gerwig pulls off an incredible trick: Somehow, she makes an inherently unlikable character, likable. It's one of the year's most intriguing and unmissable performances, and it confirms that Gerwig is among the brightest talents on the cinema scene.
"Grandma" is a small film, but one with huge things to say about the meaning of family and the value of living on one's own terms.
Oyelowo and Mara achieve terrific chemistry. Perhaps they'll work together again - in a better film.

In one of his strongest and most impressive performances, Maguire goes all in on Fischer's quirks and insecurities. Although Fischer is unquestionably a genius, he's not an easy person to like, and Maguire brilliantly gets that point across.

In a way, "Stonewall" is proof that the gay community has fully made the transition to the mainstream. It's now subject to the kind of Hollywood nonsense that was previously reserved for heterosexuals.
These days, it's tough to find a comedy that even aspires to sophistication. "The Intern" entertainingly fills that slot.
"Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation" proves that a summer flick can be as smart as it is exciting.
Gordon-Levitt beguilingly captures Petit's irresistible charisma in a performance that completes his transition from indie-film favorite to big-budget star.
Among the virtues of "Mississippi Grind" is an unpredictability that's rare in movies these days. For much of the film, it's unclear just where it's going - and that's just fine.
Bahrani nails the predicament in which so many working-class folks now find themselves. Although they cling to the American dream, for many of them it has become a nightmare.
Wright seems overwhelmed by the material, and he fails to make us care about any of the characters.
Despite its genre constraints, "Bridge of Spies" is among Spielberg's finest achievements - and a reminder that the past is much more than just a repository for nostalgia.
"Freeheld" is a snapshot of a notable American moment.
As original and risk-taking as its subject, "Steve Jobs" will make you think differently about an American icon.
In Bullock, "Crisis" has a star who makes the whole thing seem better than it probably is.
With visual and psychological precision, Abrahamson brilliantly evokes the experience of living outside of everyday reality. And he does so without resorting to either creepiness or sentimentality.
"Spectre" isn't bad - just slightly disappointing.
Disappointingly formulaic.
Struggles heroically, but unsuccessfully, to strike a balance between whimsy and pathos.
Far from being just another crime story, "Sicario" is cinema at its most ambitious.

"Third Person" doesn't lack for ambition, and it's nice to see Neeson in the kind of role that he excelled at before he morphed into an action star. But the film may have some folks wishing they'd bought a ticket to "Transformers 4" instead.
Spending time with "Irrational Man" would not be an irrational choice.
"Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" is a must-see - and one of the best films of the year.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Arteta keeps the action speeding along while eliciting spot-on performances. Carell is at his discombobulated best, and Garner anchors the proceedings with aplomb.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "Fury" is a guided tour through a manmade hell.
"The Book of Life" is a flawed but intriguing new chapter in animation.
Lots of films claim to be different. "Birdman" is.
Despite its intriguing premise, the film amounts to little more than tedious, clichÃ©d melodramatics.
Ultimately, "Whiplash" isn't just about jazz - and it's not necessary to be a fan of the music to enjoy the film - but about life.
If the film introduces more people to Terry's music, it will have more than served its purpose.
"Laggies" is the kind of indie film that gives the genre a bad name.
The storytelling is solid, propelled by characters that you come to care about. And that should make "Big Hero 6" a big hit.
"Rosewater" is a reminder that America may have its critics, but at least there's little danger of the average citizen being arrested for appearing on a fake news show.
A relentless procession of animated mayhem that has little to do with classical storytelling, and everything to do with the imperative of cynically pandering to short attention spans.
"Infinitely Polar Bear" is a much-needed reminder that the realm of film is still a place to encounter something other than comic-book scenarios.

Swank, an Oscar winner for "Boys Don't Cry" and "Million Dollar Baby," is outstanding, getting to the essence of Mary Bee's pride and pain. And in the showier role, Jones impressively peels away layers of rambunctiousness to reveal George's humanity.
"Annie" is not a great movie musical - but it's a fun time at the movies.
In a role that would have been ideal for Tom Cruise in psycho mode, Wahlberg is merely OK. Unfortunately, the film's effectiveness turns on whether we buy into his angst.
Throughout his career, Burton has always been capable of surprising audiences. "Big Eyes" is no exception.
In an era of comic-book movies, "Selma" is an impressive reminder of the real-life struggle for human dignity.
"A Most Violent Year" is a far more interesting film than its title implies. And a film you've never seen before.
As with their previous films, the brothers cast a discerning gaze on working-class lives, without preachiness or sentimentality.
At its core, "Ballet 422" addresses a universal theme: The importance of having a dream, and the courage and dedication to make it come true.
Brilliant performances aside, "Clouds of Sils Maria" is overlong and much too self-indulgently an "art film." It might have benefited from being just a bit more grounded.
It doesn't help that the characters caught up in this fact-based melodrama aren't particularly engaging. Or that TÃ©chinÃ© doesn't seem to have much of a feel for the material.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "I'll See You in My Dreams" is at once funny and poignant - and not just for moviegoers of a certain age.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Saint Laurent was a truly mythic figure. It's a shame that Bonello's film doesn't do him justice.
With "Top Five," Rock has finally made the transition to true movie stardom.
This film might easily have settled for mocking religion. Instead, it's a fascinating glimpse into a culture that forces some people to choose between fitting in and opting out.
A thoroughly engrossing tale of conflicting agendas and thwarted ambition. In its verve and verisimilitude, the film recalls such classics of political cinema as Z and The Battle of Algiers.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: "Brighton Rock" doesn't rise to classic status, but it's an intriguing mood piece.
Rudo y Cursi never quite figures out what it wants to be. Is it a sports comedy? A tale of sibling rivalry? A look at Mexico's gritty underbelly, set against a soccer backdrop?

Cheri may be too leisurely paced for the Fast & Furious and Terminator Salvation crowd. But if you're in the mood for a warm bath rather than a quick shower, you might find this bittersweet period piece quite moving.
As sophisticated as it is entertaining, Public Enemies isn't the sort of film that's usually associated with the summer. But it has more than enough firepower to be a blockbuster.
Ultimately, Moon isn't quite the transcendent experience that it clearly strives to be. But as ambitious science fiction, it achieves liftoff.
Bostick turns in a quietly mesmerizing performance, capturing Simon's sense of loss without slipping into pathos.
The Hurt Locker is at once an unforgettable war film and a brilliant character study.

$9.99 may not be entirely successful from a dramatic perspective, and it certainly offers little enlightenment about the meaning of life. But the film is so intriguing in other ways that it's definitely worth a look.
Ponyo isn't quite as memorable as some of Miyazaki's previous works, but it's a magical experience that's far superior to most animated offerings.
After watching Post Grad, you may wonder whether Hollywood will ever stop making generic comedies with zero tolerance for originality.
It's the kind of film that Hollywood used to excel at but no longer seems interested in making.
As filmmakers, the Dardennes are more concerned with probing the causes of crime than in glamorizing it.
The Proposal could have been much smarter, and much hipper. Instead, it settles for silliness and sentimentality.
What threatens to be a mere exercise in style proves to be as involving as it is inventive.
If you think they don't make movies like they used to, "Brooklyn" is glorious proof to the contrary.
Is A Serious Man funny? Absolutely - but in much the same way as the old joke about a fellow who loved to hit his own head because it felt so good when he stopped.
No doubt some people will find Antichrist repellent. The question is whether you're open to films that are as flawed as they are ambitious.
As a melodrama, Brothers is passable entertainment. But the film squanders the opportunity to meaningfully portray the impact of war on American lives.
Youth in Revolt is a delightful film that makes no apologies for its irreverence. It's also the first great comedy of this decade.
The Book of Eli doesn't quite achieve the greatness to which it so clearly aspires. But how many sci-fi flicks have Al Green on the soundtrack?
In Hollywood, it's all about the concept, and some studio executive must have thought it would be fun to watch Adams slogging around in the Irish mud. Unfortunately, there's no accounting for taste.
It's a step backward for Johnson, a charismatic performer who was much better in Race to Witch Mountain. A few more films like this, and he may be back to professional wrestling.
Dear John fulfills its mission, which is to be a crowd-pleasing tearjerker.
Claire Denis, an acclaimed French director, makes films that defy the rules of Hollywood.
The White Ribbon is a stark, contemplative and hauntingly brilliant film.
Although the film begins promisingly, it proves to be little more than a soap opera.
For a popcorn flick, it has style and smarts. And while it's not an actors' film, it offers solid performances.
Scott keeps things tense while allowing for the occasional blast of humor.
Every Little Step never rises above being a very good showbiz documentary. But it's an engaging tribute to a groundbreaking musical.
If you really want to laugh, The Original Kings of Comedy is the picture to see.
[A] perfunctory blend of cheap shocks and fashionable murkiness.
A brilliant satire on modern American life.
Taken simply as a popcorn flick, National Treasure has its pleasures.
An indelible portrait of the contradictions of power.
A film that exceeds expectations. Without skimping on the thrills and action, DÃ©jÃ  Vu is surprisingly thoughtful in its observations regarding the possible repercussions of tampering with the past.
Zodiac, the latest film from director David Fincher, is among his best
Winterbottom's gritty sensibility and feel for geopolitical realities is perfect for the film. There's no room for Hollywood gloss - and no need for it.
Brad Pitt as Jesse James: Seldom has an actor been so perfectly cast.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: On its own terms, Step Brothers is hilarious. But it's a shame that the filmmakers didn't have more faith in the audience. Why resort to gross-out tactics when your premise is strong enough to allow for a more sophisticated approach?
Downey is at his charismatic best, rendering believable Stark's transformation from self-indulgent jerk to socially conscious crusader.

Easy Virtue has all the elements for a sprightly romp with serious underpinnings, and occasionally it achieves that balance. But it's marred by attempts at farce that are as belabored as they are ill-advised.
Smith turns in a terrific performance, nailing Neville's angst while allowing room for humor.
Plays often lose their energy when adapted for the screen. But even on the stage, Frost/Nixon had a cinematic dynamism, and Howard has only enhanced that quality.
Duplicity may be too smart for its own good. But how many films can you say that about?
Diesel is still charismatic thug Dominic Toretto, Walker is still determined cop Brian O'Conner, and the story is still dumb.
Crowe turns in a strong performance as the conflicted McAffrey. McAdams is equally convincing as Frye, who gets a quick education in journalistic basics.
If you're a Francophile, it may be worth a look. But it's no Moulin Rouge.
Those who seek a drama as provocative as it is captivating will find much to enjoy.
A terrific film that's not just for sports fans. Written and directed by Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck, it's as insightful as it is entertaining.
Working from a screenplay by Peter Harness, director John Crowley elicits strong performances and conjures a realistic atmosphere. But the story is predictable.

Goodbye Solo is the sort of film that truly defies categorization, and that may pose a challenge to some moviegoers. But there are certain works of art to which the rules do not apply. This is one of them.
It's a quiet but heartfelt film that has a lot to say about the allure of the past and the inevitability of change.
The film may be ahead of its time -- or it may just be an elaborate put-on.
What's galling about Eagle Eye is that it could easily have been an entertaining film without constantly yielding to the impulse to blow stuff up.
"Warrior" could have used a bit more guts. But it's still a knockout.
Perhaps tracking down the folks responsible for this film should be Milo's next assignment.
A Prophet is essential viewing for art-film buffs and crime-flick fans, but also for anyone who's looking for a great story, terrific acting and masterful filmmaking.
Suspenseful, romantic and wryly funny, "The Adjustment Bureau" is the kind of film that reaffirms one's faith in Hollywood.
Skarsgard, who is perhaps best known for "Good Will Hunting" and "Breaking the Waves," makes the most of his rich role, imbuing Ulrik with a knockabout charm.
Araki deserves credit for maintaining his independent spirit. But "Kaboom" is short on impact.
A terrific but uncompromising film that's definitely not for everyone. It's not just that the violence is graphic, but that much of it is so mean-spirited.
"Source Code" isn't as smart or adventurous as it might have been. But as popcorn entertainment, it's right on schedule.
If the late director Krzysztof Kieslowski had made a mainstream film, it might have looked a lot like this one.
If you're looking for a frothy comedy, "Potiche" definitely has its charms.
A stylish reminder of a bygone time when historical epics were very much a part of mainstream filmmaking.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "The Beaver" isn't a perfect film, but it's challenging and original.
If you liked "Dressed to Kill" or "Blow Out," you'll appreciate the ways in which "The Double Hour" artfully messes with your mind.
"The Robber" is artfully done but emotionally remote.
There's also little sense of what these characters were like before reality came crashing down on them.
Maintains a wonderful balance between grit and grace.
"Larry Crowne" proves that it's possible to be funny without being crude. But more than that, it's as easygoing as the character for which it's named.
With a little help from films like this, Fischer could trade her small-screen fame for multiplex stardom.
"Terri" is a challenging but rewarding throwback to a time when independent films weren't just stepping stones on the road to Hollywood.
Perhaps one day, Hathaway and Sturgess will reunite in a more emotionally satisfying romance.
Put aside any hang-ups you may have about subtitles. As action flicks go, "Point Blank" is right on target.
Rudd is at his best, imbuing Ned with a deep humanity and a surprisingly persuasive edge. And as the sisters, Banks, Deschanel and Mortimer never hit a wrong note.
"The Debt" eventually settles into a predictable groove that slightly undercuts its impact. Still, it's a film of ambition and substance.
The film may leave some viewers even more confused about the Madoff affair than they were in the first place.
"The Tree" might have suffered from too much symbolism if not for writer-director Julie Bertuccelli's deft touch and Gainsbourg's appealing performance.
Sitting through "A Good Old Fashioned Orgy" is like being monopolized by the most irritating person at a really boring party.
"Contagion" is a thoughtful, provocative and ultimately chilling film.
A strange and beautiful film.
Egoyan's trademark quirkiness definitely makes its presence felt.
White Material is unhurried in its storytelling but unshakable in its impact.
About the best thing that can be said for the film is that Portman and Kutcher have just enough chemistry to make its premise work.
What starts out as a tale of serial killing quickly becomes even more sinister and complex.
Charming but insignificant.
When it comes to combining vulnerability and menace, nobody does it quite like Caine.
A thoughtful and provocative film about the way we live now.
Less than an hour and a half long, it seems to take forever to end.
In a Holofcener film, the usual rules of screenwriting do not apply, which lends her work a lifelike quality that's particularly refreshing in this era of formulaic remakes and sequels.
It's a smart, funny film that flirts with the edge.
Knight and Day is an action comedy that works. But it's also a surprisingly poignant romance. This is the summer flick you've been waiting for.
Jeunet remains one of the world's most imaginative directors. But Micmacs is a misfire.
What it has going for it, however, is a strong performance from Clarkson, who has become one of the more reliable character actors in independent film.
Clooney turns in an intense performance that owes little to his usual roguish charm.

Portman hasn't been this good since her early performances in The Professional and Heat, and is deservedly attracting intense Oscar buzz. Kunis brings to Lily a savvy sexiness, and Cassel is entertainingly smarmy.
The Extra Man is a disappointment coming from Berman and Pulcini, whose American Splendor was an imaginative biopic about the late comic-book author Harvey Pekar.

Although Lebanon is to be congratulated for its bold visual strategy and strong antiwar stance, the film becomes claustrophobic after a while. When one of the characters finally emerges from the tank, you may find yourself as relieved as he is.

Fincher has made quite a few terrific films, from Se7en to the underrated Zodiac. But this time he's outdone himself. The Social Network is riveting from start to finish, and a master class in directing.

Allen has been criticized for leaving some of the plot lines up in the air and several characters in the lurch. But he seems to be making a point: Neat Hollywood endings are as phony and dangerous as Cristal's ramblings.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This unfortunately titled film has an offbeat charm that just about makes up for its short running time.
"Due Date" is pregnant with possibility; it's the delivery that disappoints.
Boyle is such a gifted filmmaker that, in his hands, 127 Hours is genuinely -- and unsentimentally -- inspirational.
Only Gugino, one of the most underrated actresses in Hollywood, displays emotional complexity - and do you really need that in an action flick? Actually, yes.
So deficient in the genre's essentials - such as witty dialogue, intriguing characters and surprising yet credible plot turns - that you're embarrassed for everyone involved.
"How Do You Know" is a bit slow to get started, and it's nowhere near as funny as "The Hangover." But it'll make you smile.
Seth Rogen is the Green Hornet. What else do you need to know?
A tough, raw drama about wounds that heal only gradually, if at all.
There's no denying its strong narrative or its emotional pull. And the film's computer-influenced visual style is very much of the moment.
Helgeland clearly has a feel for the Krays' criminal milieu, but it's not long before repetition sets in. There's only so much brutality that even the most bloodthirsty audience can tolerate.
It's a well-crafted film that wears its old-fashionedness with pride.
"Chi-Raq" doesn't always work, but it's a film that dares to take chances.
"The Wall" is merely an exercise in empty intensity. Watching it feels too much like being trapped in it.
Is romantic comedy dead? Not as long as the genre can accommodate a film as uniquely wonderful as "The Lovers."
Depp, who once was among the most risk-taking actors in film, seems to be merely going through the motions.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film of subtle humor and universal appeal. Just don't expect a carefree romp.
Working from her own screenplay, director Robin Swicord delivers a film that balances wry humor and sly introspection.
If you have a soft spot for dogs, this is a love story you'll find irresistible.
"My Cousin Rachel" is more of an exercise in style than an adventure in emotion. In the competition for the multiplex dollar, it's relatively unmemorable.
As a performer, Lister-Jones acquits herself well on both the comedic and melodramatic fronts. And the scruffily charming Pally comes across as a hybrid of Seth Rogen and Paul Rudd.
"Beatriz at Dinner" is a meal of a film, with plenty to chew on.
It's the kind of action-comedy that makes you want to see it again a second after it's over.
It's one of his finest and most memorable performances. Unfortunately, the script fails to rise to the level of Elliott's artistry.
Another big-screen adaptation of this story probably wasn't necessary. But as unnecessary films go, it's well worth a look.
"The Big Sick" has a lot of charm.
"Maudie" is a work of art.
"Valerian" has some cool visuals. But there's more to science fiction than pretty pictures.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Seldom has a film so eloquently captured the craziness, brutality and arbitrariness of war. "Dunkirk" just might be Nolan's masterpiece.
You may not understand "A Ghost Story." But you won't forget it.
"Atomic Blonde" is no James Bond adventure, but it's sure to satisfy action junkies.
A fascinating portrait of empowerment gone awry.
Relentless in its storytelling, "Detroit" is a film of blistering impact.
This film will give you a new appreciation for the freedoms that are often taken for granted in a democracy.
An informative documentary that's certain to bolster awareness of an ongoing cause for alarm.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You may not agree with the politics of "Whose Streets?" But its power and passion are undeniable.
This is a film of subtle beauty.
Norman may be a mere wannabe, but "Norman" is a small gem.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Vol. 2" might have been a bit more focused. Still, it's an imaginative romp that once again reflects Gunn's unique and irreverent sensibility.
This is a tough film that deals with serious issues, and that may hurt its box-office chances. But "Graduation" will probably be around long after less challenging fare is forgotten.
"20th Century Women" takes a while to kick in but eventually finds its groove.
"Gold" is a major disappointment - a film of admirable ambition but woefully underwhelming execution.
"Julieta" is a paean to longing, regret and the often painful experience of being human.
A film so low in energy that it's almost as if it was made to assist airline passengers in falling asleep.
Despite considerable progress, the film suggests, much work remains to be done - and Baldwin's voice remains as relevant as ever.
Reeves is thoroughly persuasive as a killer who takes pride in his expertise. The role he began with 2014's "John Wick" is tailor-made for his laconic acting style.
Hosseini is impressive as a man who feels compelled to take action, regardless of the ramifications. And Alidoosti persuasively embodies Rana's pain.
HÃ¼ller is amusingly discombobulated as the uptight Ines. But the film is perhaps best appreciated as a showcase for the gifted Simonischek, whose portrayal of Winfried/Toni is one for the ages.
Oyelowo captures Seretse's quiet dignity while also hinting at the limits of his patience. And Pike is compelling as a woman who rises to the occasion regardless of the circumstances.
There's no dialogue, the pace is quite slow and the meaning of the story is subject to interpretation. Yet once you're on its wavelength, the film is a mesmerizing experience.
If being seated at Table 19 is a drag, watching the film of the same name is worse.
Larson turns in an engaging performance as a woman uncertain about just who she wants to be. But Harrelson comes close to upstaging her, imbuing Rex with a bold and intriguing complexity.
If this is indeed Jackman's final appearance as Logan, he's going out in style.
"The Sense of an Ending" does not provide easy answers. But it raises intriguing questions.
"Wilson" isn't a bad film, but it could have used less melodrama and a lot more insight.
Assayas is among France's most respected filmmakers, but just what he was attempting to do with this film is something of a mystery.
Some moviegoers will find the experience frustrating; others will be exhilarated by a film that's far afield from the usual formulas.
"The Zookeeper's Wife" is little more than an old-fashioned melodrama, but for some moviegoers that will be enough.

Caine deftly balances world-weariness and stoic resolve. Freeman virtually radiates hard-won wisdom. And Arkin, as usual, is the ultimate curmudgeon. Together, they create a dynamic not unlike that of a jazz combo in which each player is fully engaged.
Young children will be entertained, but for the rest of the audience, pretty colors just aren't enough.
"Gifted" is an engaging comedy-drama that avoids becoming too much of a tearjerker.
Diesel and Johnson are at their testosterone-charged best. Theron, who seems to be auditioning to become the next Bond villain, is ruthlessness personified.
If you long for a film in the tradition of such grown-up entertainments as "Lawrence of Arabia" and "The English Patient," this is one to get lost in.
A criminal waste of an ensemble cast that should have found something better to do than lend their names to such a pointless exercise.
If you're looking for a film that offers pure escapism, "Kong: Skull Island" should definitely meet expectations.
Perhaps "Logan Lucky" is best appreciated as a stealth commentary on tough times in America. It takes a director of Soderbergh's gifts to actually make that funny.
Although "13 Minutes" is a period piece, it addresses issues that continue to resonate in society.
A stylish drama that assumes a reasonable amount of gray matter on the part of the viewer.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Far from being a dry biopic, "Darkest Hour" reminds us that some things - such as honor and freedom - are worth fighting for.
"The Shape of Water" is one of the best films of the year.
In a world bursting with flashy popcorn movies, there's still nothing quite like a "Star Wars" flick.
Like the fairground ride for which it's named, "Wonder Wheel" is entertaining but not enlightening.
The film is best appreciated as a showcase for Jackman, who makes a dazzling Barnum and holds on to our sympathies even as the character proves to be something of a heel.
"Call Me By Your Name" is a visually stunning coming-of-age story that boasts a star-making performance by Chalamet.
The film then wanders into murky, puzzling territory, leaving viewers to wonder exactly what the story was all about.
This tale of an unscrupulous and egocentric billionaire couldn't possibly be timelier.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a "Game" that couldn't be more fun to watch.
"Phantom Thread" is the kind of film that's rarely made anymore - uncompromising, sophisticated and smart.
Starts off as a smart thriller in the Hitchcock tradition. Unfortunately, the film soon goes off the rails.
Franco delivers a comedy that's delightfully offbeat. It probably helps if you've actually seen "The Room," but you can safely spare yourself that experience.
In an era in which journalistic outlets are increasingly accused of delivering "fake news," this film is a reminder that few things are as precious - and vital - as the truth.
"12 Strong" lacks depth but fulfills its mission to entertain.
Clearly influenced by classic Westerns, particularly the films of director John Ford, "Hostiles" is a worthy addition to the genre.
Bening is outstanding as a woman who fears that her fame and beauty are slipping away, and Bell ("Billy Elliot") brings to his character a heartbreaking vulnerability.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Believe the hype: "Black Panther" transcends its comic-book origins, achieving a mythic grandeur that's nothing short of exhilarating.
"Happy End" is an art film in the classic sense - ambitious, provocative and hard to shake off.
A science-fiction flick that's at once intellectually ambitious and extremely frightening.
In our increasingly polarized time, "A Fantastic Woman" bridges the gap between ignorance and understanding through the transcendent power of art.
"Red Sparrow" clearly aspires to be a spy thriller in the classic tradition - all the elements are in place. It's the execution that's woefully lacking.
It's hard to understand what went wrong - the cast couldn't be more appealing, and the film is bursting with special effects. But as an emotionally satisfying experience, it's a bust.
Although the film is a bit too schematic in its updating of film noir, it also signals a talent to watch. And Finley elicits fine work from his cast.
Often, extending a movie franchise signifies a lack of imagination. But "Creed" is a knockout.
Anyone interested in the ways in which diplomacy works - and how it sometimes doesn't - will find the documentary educational and perhaps even enlightening.
Not just another biopic, "The Founder" is a morality tale that raises provocative questions about consumer culture, its benefits and its consequences. You won't look at a Big Mac the same way again.
This origin story relies far too heavily on the Dickens tale without adding much interest.
"Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is entertaining in a way that's practically unheard of these days.
This film may not exactly be a "Good Time," but it's an interesting one.
Stanfield deftly balances rage and resignation, and Asomugha is impressive as a crusader who refuses to give up.
If you're looking for a film that's guaranteed to have you gripping your seat, this is "It."
This is a movie that Holden would have skipped.
Naysayers will no doubt argue that "mother!" is an incomprehensible mess. But as sheer visceral filmmaking, it's a must-see.
This is the rare mainstream film that addresses the complexities of real life. "Brad's Status" may motivate you to question your own.
"Stronger" could have been little more than a melodrama. Instead, it's a surprisingly gritty film about refusing to give up, regardless of the odds.
"American Made" is a stinging critique of U.S. foreign policy disguised as a freewheeling action comedy.
This is mainstream filmmaking at the top of its game.
"Blade Runner 2049" is not just a movie but an event. Don't be the only human on your block not to see it.
Some of the plot turns seem a bit too convenient, and the film goes on for too long. But ultimately, it's a showcase for a pair of excellent actors who elevate the material.
Neither an indictment nor an endorsement of war, "Last Flag Flying" reclaims patriotism as a uniter, not a divider.
"Marshall" is one of the freshest and most entertaining films of the year.
The cast is first-rate, notably Neeson in the title role. "Mark Felt" benefits mightily from his very particular set of acting skills.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hall ... delivers an understated drama that makes its points without preachiness. If the film doesn't quite achieve greatness, it's nonetheless heartfelt.
If you're merely out for a good time at the movies, you can safely skip "Suburbicon." But true film buffs will want to peek behind the blinds of Clooney's latest directorial endeavor.
If your goal is to spend a few hours escaping from reality, "Thor: Ragnarok" is definitely for you.
Although Branagh delivers a film that's reasonably watchable, the not-so-mysterious truth is that "Murder on the Orient Express" didn't need to be remade.
Those who are merely looking for a flick that goes well with popcorn may be bored, but true cinema buffs will be in heaven.
This is the feel-bad film of the year. Recommend it to someone you hate.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Wonder" is a family film in the best sense.
A film in which solid storytelling is neglected in favor of grandiose but ultimately empty special effects.
Lots of movies are set to be popping up in multiplexes, but few as wonderful as "Lady Bird."
Most films, especially mainstream ones, are about the forces that whirl around characters. "Novitiate" grapples with what's going on inside them.
"Breathe" is obvious Oscar bait, but its engaging story and appealing cast make that agenda easy to excuse.
Far from being exploitative, "Patriots Day" honors the Bostonians who responded to terrorism with strength.
If you thought it was a bad idea to mess with a classic, "Beauty and the Beast" will persuade you that a tale as old as time is worth retelling.
It's a perfect vehicle for Driver, who endearingly captures the hangdog humility of his character.
It's not necessary to be a jazz fan to get lost in this poetic and poignant film.
If you're interested in Williams and his music, this film is better than nothing - but not by much.
Offbeat and unpredictable, "Demolition" takes a wrecking ball to audience expectations.
